sub_topic: Precision measurements of the weak interaction
message_1: What is the probability of the decay of a free neutron to the final state with a proton, electron, and antineutrino given a time of 15 minutes, assuming the neutron is at rest and there are no external factors affecting the decay process?
message_2:
To calculate the probability of a free neutron decaying into a proton, electron, and antineutrino within a given time, we can use the formula:

P(t) = 1 - e^(-t/τ)

where P(t) is the probability of decay within time t, τ is the mean lifetime of a neutron, and e is the base of the natural logarithm (approximately 2.71828).

The mean lifetime of a free neutron is approximately 881.5 seconds. To find the probability of decay within 15 minutes (900 seconds), we can plug in the values into the formula:

P(900) = 1 - e^(-900/881.5)

P(900) = 1 - e^(-1.021)

P(900) ≈ 1 - e^(-1)

P(900) ≈ 1 - 0.368

P(900) ≈ 0.632

So, the probability of a free neutron decaying into a proton, electron, and antineutrino within 15 minutes is approximately 63.2%.
